options.c: A section of code that is exempt from synchronization
options.d: A section of code responsible for memory allocation

    int i;
    float f;
    char str[20];
};

    data.i = 10;
    data.f = 20.5;
    
    printf("%d, %f", data.i, data.f);
    
    return 0;
}

What is the output of the following program?
using namespace std;

class A {
public:
    virtual void display() {
        cout << "A";
    }
};

class B : public A {
public:
    void display() override {
        cout << "B";
    }
};

int main() {
    A* ptr = new B;
    ptr->display();
    delete ptr;
    return 0;
}
Which of the following statements about friend functions and friend classes in C++ is false?

options.a: Friend functions can be declared in the private or public section of a class.
options.b: Friend functions and friend classes violate encapsulation.
options.c: Friendship is mutual; if class A is a friend of class B, then class B is automatically a friend of class A.
options.d: Friend functions and friend classes have access to private and protected members of the class they are friends with.

questions.question:
What is the output of the following code?
using namespace std;

class Base {
public:
    Base() {
        cout << "Base ";
    }
};

class Derived : public Base {
public:
    Derived() {
        cout << "Derived ";
    }
};

int main() {
    Derived d;
    return 0;
}
Which of the following is true about template specialization in C++?

options.a: It allows specialization of functions but not classes.
options.b: It is not allowed in C++.
options.c: It allows providing a different implementation for a specific type.
options.d: It is used to specify default template arguments.

questions.question:
What will be the output of the following program?
using namespace std;

class A {
public:
    virtual void print() {
        cout << "A";
    }
};

class B : public A {
public:
    void print() override {
        cout << "B";
    }
};

int main() {
    A obj;
    A* ptr = &obj;
    B* bptr = dynamic_cast(ptr);
    if (bptr) {
        bptr->print();
    } else {
        cout << "C";
    }
    return 0;
}

What is the output of the following code?
using namespace std;

class Base {
public:
    virtual void print() {
        cout << "Base";
    }
};

class Derived : public Base {
public:
    void print() override {
        cout << "Derived";
    }
};

int main() {
    Derived d;
    Base* ptr = &d;
    ptr->print();
    return 0;
}
Which of the following statements about static members in C++ is incorrect?

options.a: Static members can be accessed using the scope resolution operator.
options.b: Static members are shared among all instances of the class.
options.c: Static members can be initialized inside the class declaration.
options.d: Static members can be declared as const.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about operator overloading is false?

options.a: An overloaded operator must have at least one operand that is a user-defined type.
options.b: Overloaded operators can have default arguments.
options.c: Overloaded operators must preserve the precedence and associativity of the built-in operators.
options.d: Overloaded operators cannot change the fundamental meaning of the operators.

    int nextDay = today + 1;
    
    printf("%d", nextDay);
    
    return 0;
}

options.b: They can be singly or doubly linked.

questions.question: Which of the following are true about the find command in Unix?

options.a: It is used to search for files and directories.
options.b: It supports searching by name, size, and modification time.
options.c: It can execute commands on the files found.
options.d: It only searches in the current directory.

options.b: The kill command can be used to send signals.

options.b: It is used in systems requiring high reliability and predictability.
options.d: It is suitable for time-critical applications.

options.b: They include algorithms like FCFS, SSTF, and SCAN.
options.c: They have no impact on system performance.
options.d: They aim to reduce seek time and latency.

options.c: Routers operate at the Network Layer.
options.d: Routing tables are used to determine the best path for data packets.

questions.question: Which of the following are true about UDP (User Datagram Protocol)?

options.b: It ensures data integrity and reliability.
options.d: It is suitable for real-time applications like video streaming.

questions.question: Which of the following are true about indexing in a database?

options.b: It can slow down data insertion and updates.
options.d: It eliminates the need for primary keys.

options.c: They can be document-based, key-value stores, column-oriented, or graph databases.
options.d: They are suitable for distributed data storage.
